Description: Can you detect a gravitational wave? In Black Hole Hunter, your objective is to listen to gravitational wave detector data and determine whether or not you can hear the given gravitational wave signal in the sound file, or whether it is just noise.
LIGO is by no means the first experiment to detect black holes, with x-ray measurements suggesting their presence. This simple web-tool compares the sizes and masses of known black holes.
The LIGO measurements reveal an awful lot about the black holes in the detected systems. This web-tool allows you to explore what we know in the form of an interactive graph.
Based on Chromoscope, Gravoscope shows the locations on the sky that detected gravitational waves originated.

Resource Name: Searching for Gravitational Waves in Noisy Data
Description:
A range of educational resources relating to gravitational waves:
  • Searching for Gravitational Waves in Noisy Data (PSU)
  • Hands-on Gravitational Wave Astronomy: Extraction of Astrophysical Information from Simulated Signals (PSU)
  • Various other LIGO Classroom Activities
Hands-on resources based on extraction of astrophysical information from simulated signals
A range of classroom activities created by the LIGO community
Summaries of the scientific papers published about on LIGO/Virgo science and technology, but explained for a more general audience

This workshop gives students the opportunity to analyse and interpret gravitational wave data. The activity is in two parts, one calculating the distance to the source, and the other determining the redshift. These results are then combined to determine the Hubble constant - the rate of expansion of the Universe.

There are 8 sets of data, so that allows for the possibility of 16 "teams", with pairs of teams using the same dataset.
Play with masses of detections compared against that from EM observations
Play with sensitivity of current and future detector network
Author/Originator: C. Moore, R. Cole and C. Berry

Description: Play with plots of the (modeled) waveforms of detections
Author/Originator: Cardiff University (Chris North), Stuart Lowe; LIGO/Virgo Collaboration

Description:
The general theory of relativity describes gravity in a completely different way than classical physics does: In general relativity, gravity is not described as a force but rather as the interplay between mass, time, and space. When Einstein published his theory in 1915, he predicted several surprising phenomena which were later experimentally confirmed - among them the bending of light and warping of time by massive objects.

This learning resource was developed by the research and development team in the project ReleQuant, based at the University of Oslo, the Norwegian Centre for Science Education, and the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. Magdalena Kersting has been responsible for the development of the program. It has received support from the Research Council of Norway and the Olav Thon Foundation.
Website providing modular, illustrated introductory texts that introduce the fundamentals and most important applications of Einstein's theories of special and of general relativity.
Author/Originator: Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics (Albert Einstein Institute)

Resource Name: Frontiers project: Teaching modern physics in school curricula
Description: This project contains a set of "demonstrators" for teaching modern physics in high school. The demonstrators provide the targeted age, a short description and several teaching material.
Type of Resource: Collection; Online; Reading; Video; Worksheet; Lesson Plan
Author/Originator: Several authors from various countries (see demonstrators webpage)

Description: This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Laboratory website. The activity provides a simple set of star maps that students can use to learn to navigate the sky.
This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Lab website. The activity provides Web applets that correspond to some of the exhibits at LLO and LHO.
This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Laboratory website. The activity gives students an opportunity to work through the scientific method using a simple pendulum.
This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Laboratory website. The activity provides instructions for building a Michelson interferometer from inexpensive parts.

This Educational Michelson Interferometer communicates the design principles of the LIGO Observatory and provides a simple demonstration of the wave nature of light. It is also of historical significance as a derivation of the instrument was used by Michelson and Morley in their search for the nonexistent "luminiferous aether". There are many ways to build a simple interferometer; this document is intended as a recipe for a basic design inspired by "Build Your Own Michelson Interferometer". The primary difference between these two designs is that the Magnetic Michelson's use of steel plate and magnets allow it to be taken apart and re-assembled on a regular basis by new sets of students, whereas Build Your Own describes a permanent setup.

Resource Name: Build and Use a Simple Spectroscope
Description: This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Lab website. Students build a spectroscope from a cardboard box.

This is a classroom activity that's associated with the LIGO Laboratory website. This activity helps students understand the difference between linear and exponential growth. It serves as a companion to the film Powers of Ten.

A range of apps designed and built by gravitational wave researchers to explore the science and technology of gravitational wave detection:
  • Pocket Black Hole (play with the light-bending effect of a black hole)
  • Stretch and Squeeze (explore how a passing gravitational wave would stretch and squash the distances between objects)
  • Space Time Quest (A game putting you in charge of designing your own gravitational wave detector)
  • Black Hole Master (a light-hearted remake of the old classic "Pong", except with a cosmic twist!)

Chirp is a web-app that listens to the GCN system and displays the information in a friendly format, with links to LIGO-Virgo Gravitational Wave Candidate Event Database (GraceDB) pages for more detailed information. For more information about this app check out our about page.

Learn to work with data from gravitational wave observatories, using videos, tutorials, and web apps. Choose a learning path for students or researchers, and work through a suite of suggested activities.
Type of Resource: Online; Interactive; Coding; Reading; Video; Research
